sen.j: 高桐院（こうとういん）は京都府京都市北区 (京都市)紫野にある臨済宗大本山大徳寺の塔頭のひとつである。
sen.e: Koto-in Temple is a sub-temple within the precinct of Rinzai Sect Daihonzan (head temple) Daitoku-ji Temple located in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Koto-in Temple is a sub-temple within the precinct of Rinzai Sect Daihonzan (head temple) Daitoku-ji Temple located in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Koto-in Temple is a sub-temple within the precinct of Rinzai Sect Daihonzan (head temple) Daitoku-ji Temple located in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は細川忠興（三斎）、開山（初代住職）は玉甫紹琮（ぎょくほじょうそう）である。
sen.e: The kaiki (founding patron) was Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and the kaiki (founding priest) was Gyokuho Joso.
The kaiki (founding patron) was Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and the kaiki (founding priest) was Gyokuho Joso.
The kaiki (founding patron) was Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and the kaisan (founding priest) was Gyokuho Joso.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)に智将として名を馳せ、茶人としては利休七哲の1人として知られる細川忠興（三斎）が叔父の玉甫紹琮（ぎょくほじょうそう）を開山として慶長7年（1602年）創建する。
sen.e: Koto-in Temple was founded in 1602 by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, a resourceful general who made his name during the Warring States period (Japan) and one of the seven disciples of tea ceremony master Rikyu, and he named his uncle Gyokuho Joso as kaisan (founding priest).

Koto-in Temple was founded in 1602 by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, a resourceful general who made his name during the Warring States period (Japan) and one of the seven disciples of tea ceremony master Rikyu, and he named his uncle Gyokuho Joso as kaisan (founding priest).

Koto-in Temple was founded in 1602 by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, a resourceful general who made his name during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and one of the seven disciples of tea ceremony master Rikyu, and he named his uncle Gyokuho Joso as kaisan (founding priest).

sen.j: 正保2年（1645年）に83歳で没した三斎は遺言により高桐院に埋葬され、以後細川氏の菩提寺として庇護される。
sen.e: After passing away in 1645 aged 83, he was buried at Koto-in Temple according to his will and it later became patronized as the ancestral temple of the Hosokawa clan.
After passing away in 1645 aged 83, he was buried at Koto-in Temple according to his will and it later became patronized as the ancestral temple of the Hosokawa clan.
After passing away in 1645 aged 83, he was buried at Koto-in Temple according to his will and it later became patronized as the ancestral temple of the Hosokawa clan.

sen.j: 本堂（客殿）- 長谷川等伯が描いたとされる襖絵があったが、明治時代初期の廃仏毀釈で失われてしまっている。
sen.e: Main Hall (guest hall): Once housed sliding panel paintings believed to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA but these were lost as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.
Main Hall (guest hall): Once housed sliding panel paintings believed to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA but these were lost as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.

Main Hall (guest hall): Once housed sliding panel paintings believed to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA but these were lost as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji period.

sen.j: 現在の建物は三斎の末裔にあたる侯爵・細川護立（もりたつ）が寄進したものである。
sen.e: The current building was donated by Marquis Moritatsu HOSOKAWA - a descendant of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA.
The current building was donated by Marquis Moritatsu HOSOKAWA - a descendant of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA.
The current building was donated by Marquis Moritatsu HOSOKAWA - a descendant of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 庭園 - 通称「楓の庭」と呼ばれる簡素ながら趣のある庭で、一面の苔地の中に一基の灯籠が据えられている。
sen.e: Garden: The simple and elegant garden is commonly referred to as "Kaede-no-Niwa" (Maple Garden) and has a single lantern standing on the moss-covered ground.
Garden: The simple and elegant garden is commonly referred to as "Kaede-no-Niwa" (Maple Garden) and has a single lantern standing on the moss-covered ground.
Garden: The simple and elegant garden is commonly referred to as 'Kaede-no-Niwa' (Maple Garden) and has a single lantern standing on the moss-covered ground.

sen.j: 鳳来（茶室）- 裏千家・円能斎好みの茶室で、前庭に置かれている蹲踞（つくばい）は朝鮮出兵の際に加藤清正が持ち帰り、三斎に贈られたものと伝わる。
sen.e: Horai (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Ennosai of the Urasenke tea ceremony school and the stone washbasin in the front garden is said to have been brought back to Japan by Kiyomasa KATO on his return from the Imjin War on the Korean Peninsula and given to Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA as a gift.

Horai (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Ennosai of the Urasenke tea ceremony school and the stone washbasin in the front garden is said to have been brought back to Japan by Kiyomasa KATO on his return from the Imjin War on the Korean Peninsula and given to Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA as a gift.

Horai (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Ennosai of the Urasenke tea ceremony school and the stone washbasin in the front garden is said to have been brought back to Japan by Kiyomasa KATO on his return from the Imjin War on the Korean Peninsula and given to Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA as a gift.

sen.j: 書院 - 意北軒（いほくけん）と呼ばれ、千利休の邸宅を移築したといわれる。
sen.e: Shoin (study): Known as "Ihoku-ken" and said to be the relocated residence of SEN no Rikyu.
Shoin (study): Known as "Ihoku-ken" and said to be the relocated residence of SEN no Rikyu.
Shoin (study): Known as "Ihoku-ken" and said to be the relocated residence of SEN no Rikyu.

sen.j: 松向軒（しょうこうけん）- 利休の茶を忠実に継承したといわれる三斎好みの茶室で、豊臣秀吉が催した北野大茶会の際につくった茶室を移築したといわれる。
sen.e: Shoko-ken (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and is said to be true to the tea ceremony style developed by SEN no Rikyu and also said to be a relocated teahouse that was used when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI hosted the Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.

Shoko-ken (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and is said to be true to the tea ceremony style developed by SEN no Rikyu and also said to be a relocated teahouse that was used when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI hosted the Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.

Shoko-ken (teahouse): This teahouse was favored by Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and is said to be true to the tea ceremony style developed by SEN no Rikyu and also said to be a relocated teahouse that was used when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI hosted the Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.

sen.j: 墓所 - 本堂庭園には三斎公と細川ガラシャ夫人の墓塔となっている春日灯籠がある。
sen.e: Graveyard: A Kasuga type lantern that serves as the gravestone of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and his wife Garasha (Gracia) HOSOKAWA.
Graveyard: A Kasuga type lantern that serves as the gravestone of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and his wife Garasha (Gracia) HOSOKAWA.
Graveyard: A Kasuga type lantern that serves as the gravestone of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and his wife Garasha (Gracia) HOSOKAWA in the main hall garden.
sen.cmt: in the main hall garden補足

sen.j: この燈籠は三斎が生前こよなく愛し，自ら墓標に指定したといわれる。
sen.e: Tadaoki HOSOKAWA was extremely fond of this lantern and it is said that he selected it to serve as his grave marker.
Tadaoki HOSOKAWA was extremely fond of this lantern and it is said that he selected it to serve as his grave marker.
Tadaoki HOSOKAWA was extremely fond of this lantern and it is said that he selected it to serve as his grave marker.

sen.j: また、本堂裏手には非公開の墓地があり、三斎公とガラシャの嫡男で追放された細川忠隆こと長岡休無や、出雲阿国、名古屋山三郎の墓がある。
sen.e: There is also a graveyard that is not open to the public behind the main hall, in which Tadataka HOSOKAWA, (later named Kyumu NAGAOKA) - the eldest son of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and Garasha HOSOKAWA, IZUMO no Okuni and Sanzaburo NAGOYA are buried.

There is also a graveyard that is not open to the public behind the main hall, in which Tadataka HOSOKAWA, (later named Kyumu NAGAOKA) - the eldest son of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and Garasha HOSOKAWA, IZUMO no Okuni and Sanzaburo NAGOYA are buried.

There is also a graveyard that is not open to the public behind the main hall, in which Tadataka HOSOKAWA, (later named Kyumu NAGAOKA) - the eldest son of Tadaoki (Sansai) HOSOKAWA and Garasha HOSOKAWA, IZUMO no Okuni and Sanzaburo NAGOYA are buried.

sen.j: 絹本墨画山水図 2幅 附絹本墨画楊柳観音像 - 高桐院の開創以来伝わる2幅の山水画で、南宋の宮廷画院の画家であった李唐（りとう）作品である。
sen.e: 2 ink on silk landscape paintings including an ink on silk portrait of Yoryu Kannon-zu: These two landscape paintings came into the possession of Koto-in Temple after its founding and were painted by LI Tang of the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty imperial art institute.

2 ink on silk landscape paintings including an ink on silk portrait of Yoryu Kannon-zu: These two landscape paintings came into the possession of Koto-in Temple after its founding and were painted by LI Tang of the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty imperial art institute.

2 monochrome ink painting on silk of landscape including an monochrome ink painting on silk of portrait of Yoryu Kannon-zu: These two landscape paintings came into the possession of Koto-in Temple after its founding and were painted by LI Tang of the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty imperial art institute.

sen.j: 2幅のうち1幅に描かれた樹木の部分に「李唐画」の隠し落款（サイン）があることが確認されている。
sen.e: A hidden inscription reading "painted by LI Tang" written on one of the trees in one of the paintings has been validated.
A hidden inscription reading "painted by LI Tang" written on one of the trees in one of the paintings has been validated.
A hidden inscription reading 'painted by LI Tang' written on one of the trees in one of the paintings has been validated.

sen.j: 元は中央に楊柳観音像（国宝の「附」として指定）、左右に山水図を配した三幅対（さんぷくつい）とされていたもので、3幅とも唐の呉道子（ごどうし）の作といわれていた。
sen.e: The three pieces were originally thought to be a set consisting of the portrait of Yoryu Kannon (an addition to the National Treasure designation) at the center with the landscapes to the left and right and all three works were thought to have been created by WU Daozi.

The three pieces were originally thought to be a set consisting of the portrait of Yoryu Kannon (an addition to the National Treasure designation) at the center with the landscapes to the left and right and all three works were thought to have been created by WU Daozi.

The three pieces were originally thought to be a set consisting of the portrait of Yoryu Kannon (an addition to the National Treasure designation) at the center with the landscapes to the left and right and all three works were thought to have been created by WU Daozi.

sen.j: 絹本着色牡丹図 2幅 - 中国・元_(王朝)の花鳥画家である銭舜挙（せんしゅんきょ）の作といわれる牡丹図の傑作で、秀吉の北野大茶会に用いたとされている。
sen.e: 2 color on silk paintings of peonies: Paintings of flowers and birds dating from the Chinese Yuan Dynasty said to be the works of QIAN Shunju and thought to have been used at Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.

2 color on silk paintings of peonies: Paintings of flowers and birds dating from the Chinese Yuan Dynasty said to be the works of QIAN Shunju and thought to have been used at Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.

2 color painting on silk of peonies: A masterpiece of peonies dating from the Chinese Yuan Dynasty said to be the works of QIAN Shunju of paintings of flowers and birds and thought to have been used at Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Great Kitano Tea Ceremony.
sen.cmt: 絹本着色用語統一牡丹図の傑作で補足

sen.j: 絹本着色稲葉良籌（いなばりょうちゅう）像
sen.e: Color on silk portrait of Ryochu INABA
Color on silk portrait of Ryochu INABA
Color painting on silk of portrait of Ryochu INABA

sen.j: 玉甫紹琮像 - 高桐院の開山・玉甫紹琮64歳の頂相で、長谷川等伯最晩年の作と伝わる。
sen.e: Portrait of Gyokuho Joso: A portrait of Koto-in Temple founding priest Gyokuho Joso aged 64 thought to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA.
Portrait of Gyokuho Joso: A portrait of Koto-in Temple founding priest Gyokuho Joso aged 64 thought to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA.
Portrait of Gyokuho Joso: A portrait of Koto-in Temple founding priest Gyokuho Joso aged 64 thought to be the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA's last years.

sen.j: 細川忠興像
sen.e: Portrait of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA
Portrait of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA
Portrait of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA

sen.j: 高士騎驢図屏風 - 長谷川等伯の作とほぼ確認できる四曲一隻の屏風で、明治の廃仏毀釈によって寺外に一時流出していた。
sen.e: Folding screen painting of a man riding a donkey: A four-panel folding screen confidently verified as the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA that temporarily left the temple as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.

Folding screen painting of a man riding a donkey: A four-panel folding screen confidently verified as the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA that temporarily left the temple as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.

Folding screen painting of a man riding a donkey: A four-panel folding screen confidently verified as the work of Tohaku HASEGAWA that temporarily left the temple as a result of the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji period.

sen.j: 日吉山王祭礼屏風 - 滋賀県大津市・日吉大社の山王祭を描いた六曲一双の屏風で、根拠は乏しいが土佐派を再興した土佐光起（とさみつおき）の作と伝わる。
sen.e: Hie Sanno-sai Festival folding screen: A pair of six-panel folding screens depicting the Sanno-sai Festival held at Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture that are said to be the work of Mitsuoki TOSA of the Tosa School despite little evidence.

Hie Sanno-sai Festival folding screen: A pair of six-panel folding screens depicting the Sanno-sai Festival held at Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture that are said to be the work of Mitsuoki TOSA of the Tosa School despite little evidence.

Hiyoshi Sanno-sai Festival folding screen: A pair of six-panel folding screens depicting the Sanno-sai Festival held at Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture that are said to be the work of Mitsuoki TOSA of the Tosa School despite little evidence.

sen.j: 青井戸茶碗 - 「緑毛」の銘がある井戸茶碗の名品で、利休が愛用したものと言われる。
sen.e: Blue Ido tea bowl: This Ido tea bowl with the inscription 'Ryokumo' is a fine example of an Ido tea bowl and SEN no Rikyu is said to have been highly fond of using it.
Blue Ido tea bowl: This Ido tea bowl with the inscription 'Ryokumo' is a fine example of an Ido tea bowl and SEN no Rikyu is said to have been highly fond of using it.
Blue Ido tea bowl: This Ido tea bowl with the inscription 'Ryokumo' is a fine example of an Ido tea bowl and SEN no Rikyu is said to have been highly fond of using it.

sen.j: JR京都駅より京都市バス・大徳寺前（約30分）下車、徒歩約10分
sen.e: Take the Kyoto City Bus from JR Kyoto Station to "Daito-ji mae" bus stop (approximately 30 minutes) and walk for approximately 10 minutes.
Take the Kyoto City Bus from JR Kyoto Station to "Daito-ji mae" bus stop (approximately 30 minutes) and walk for approximately 10 minutes.
Take the Kyoto City Bus from JR Kyoto Station to Daitoku-ji mae bus stop (approximately 30 minutes) and walk for approximately 10 minutes.
